message.content: Yes, the authors discuss whether the data they are using/curating contains personally identifiable information or offensive content in the appendix section A.3. The authors mention that they do not release any data as part of their work, and by working with widely-used computer vision benchmarks, they restrict themselves to imagery that is available in the public domain, thereby minimizing the risk of containing harmful content or leaking personal information. Furthermore, they manually verify that no personally identifiable information or harmful content is present in the archives curated by ReCo when they use the LAION-5B dataset for qualitative studies.

Yes, the authors briefly discuss whether the data they are using/curating contains personally identifiable information or offensive content in the Appendix section A.3. They state that they do not release any data as part of their work and work primarily with widely used computer vision benchmarks, which are available in the public domain. They believe the risk of using harmful content or contributing to the leakage of personal information is low. For their use of the LAION-5B dataset for qualitative studies, they manually verify that no personally identifiable information or harmful content was present in the archives curated by ReCo.

Yes, the authors discuss whether the data they are using/curating contains personally identifiable information or offensive content. In the Appendix (Section A.3), the authors mention that they do not release any data as part of this work and primarily work with widely used computer vision benchmarks, which are available in the public domain. They believe that their work has a low risk of building on harmful content or contributing to the leakage of personal information. Furthermore, for the LAION-5B dataset used in their qualitative studies, they manually verify that no personally identifiable information or harmful content (as judged by the authors) is present in the archives curated by ReCo.
